channel.title: Zohar Atkins / @ZoharAtkins
channel.description: Twitter feed for: @ZoharAtkins. Generated by nitter.privacydev.net

item.title:
You know what brings history to life?
Telling the story of the Exodus in such a way that it is as if you yourself left Egypt.
Everything else will go the way of oblivion.
item.dc:creator: @ZoharAtkins
item.description:

item.title: RT by @ZoharAtkins: Be on guard against supposing that reading is enough without fervor, speculation without devotion, research without wonder,… knowledge w/o charity, understanding w/o humility, study w/o divine grace, clarity without divinely inspired wisdom. — Bonaventure, Itinerarium (prologue)
item.dc:creator: @Shermanicus
item.description:
Be on guard against supposing that reading is enough without fervor, speculation without devotion, research without wonder,… knowledge w/o charity, understanding w/o humility, study w/o divine grace, clarity without divinely inspired wisdom.
— Bonaventure, Itinerarium (prologue)

item.title: R to @ZoharAtkins: This is also why we light a Menorah rather than using electric lights, for example. Oil just hits different. And the fact that its relatively defunct, low-fi, inoperative, adds to the aura.
item.dc:creator: @ZoharAtkins
item.description: This is also why we light a Menorah rather than using electric lights, for example. Oil just hits different. And the fact that its relatively defunct, low-fi, inoperative, adds to the aura.

item.title: In the legal realm, Jews opt for the technologically defunct (e.g. the hand-written Torah scroll over the Kindle version), in part because they recognized an inverse correlation between efficiency and sanctity.
item.dc:creator: @ZoharAtkins
item.description:
In the legal realm, Jews opt for the technologically defunct (e.g. the hand-written Torah scroll over the Kindle version), in part because they recognized an inverse correlation between efficiency and sanctity.

item.title:
RT by @ZoharAtkins: A tremendous post from last year on Ecclesiastes—a meditation on the insufficiency of skepticism, the compatibility of existentialism and tradition, Warren Buffet's radicalism...
...Just vintage Zohar.

item.title: RT by @ZoharAtkins: I’m looking forward to reading this. I believe there are strong reasons to believe in a transcendent loving Creator. The world is imo too aesthetically profound not to have an artist behind it. But I’d also not that believing and being religious are too distinct things. It wasn’t until Maimonides that belief became a mitzvah, formally. To be religious is not about believing in propositions but being committed to a way of life. As Kierkegaard quipped about Anselm—seeking to prove God’s existence is like a lover trying to prove the existence of his beloved while in the midst of an embrace. Why not just feel the love? One rejoinder is that belief exists for those who doubt; it is the habit of absence, a commitment in the face of distance.
item.dc:creator: @ZoharAtkins
item.description: I’m looking forward to reading this. I believe there are strong reasons to believe in a transcendent loving Creator. The world is imo too aesthetically profound not to have an artist behind it. But I’d also not that believing and being religious are too distinct things. It wasn’t until Maimonides that belief became a mitzvah, formally. To be religious is not about believing in propositions but being committed to a way of life. As Kierkegaard quipped about Anselm—seeking to prove God’s existence is like a lover trying to prove the existence of his beloved while in the midst of an embrace. Why not just feel the love? One rejoinder is that belief exists for those who doubt; it is the habit of absence, a commitment in the face of distance.

item.title:
Humble-brag reviews of o1-pro be like:
It’s really hard for me to outsmart 100b of capex, but if pressed I can do it.

item.title:
Why Read Great Books?
Montaigne: To know ourselves Arnold: To meet greatness Nietzsche: To create values Weil: To learn attention Emerson: To see anew
item.dc:creator: @ZoharAtkins
item.description:
Why Read Great Books?

Montaigne: To know ourselves
Arnold: To meet greatness
Nietzsche: To create values
Weil: To learn attention
Emerson: To see anew

item.title:
Why is Torah study as great as all other commandments combined?
• Rambam: it enables right action. • Vilna Gaon: It elevates the soul. • Baal Shem Tov: It connects to God. • Rav Chaim: It shapes character. • Ramchal: It reveals hidden truths.
item.dc:creator: @ZoharAtkins
item.description:
Why is Torah study as great as all other commandments combined?

• Rambam: it enables right action.
• Vilna Gaon: It elevates the soul.
• Baal Shem Tov: It connects to God.
• Rav Chaim: It shapes character.
• Ramchal: It reveals hidden truths.
